Title: FacTool: Factuality Detection in Generative AI -- A Tool Augmented Framework for Multi-Task and Multi-Domain Scenarios
Authors: I-Chun Chern, Steffi Chern, Shiqi Chen, Weizhe Yuan, Kehua Feng, Chunting Zhou, Junxian He, Graham Neubig, Pengfei Liu
Summary: The emergence of generative pre-trained models has facilitated the synthesis of high-quality text, but it has also posed challenges in identifying factual errors in the generated text. In particular: (1) A wider range of tasks now face an increasing risk of containing factual errors when handled by generative models. (2) Generated texts tend to be lengthy and lack a clearly defined granularity for individual facts. (3) There is a scarcity of explicit evidence available during the process of fact checking. With the above challenges in mind, in this paper, we propose FacTool, a task and domain agnostic framework for detecting factual errors of texts generated by large language models (e.g., ChatGPT). Experiments on four different tasks (knowledge-based QA, code generation, mathematical reasoning, and scientific literature review) show the efficacy of the proposed method. We release the code of FacTool associated with ChatGPT plugin interface at https://github.com/GAIR-NLP/factool .

main_contribution.headline: FacTool: A Versatile Framework for Detecting Factual Errors in LLM-Generated Texts
main_contribution.description: The paper introduces FacTool, a task and domain-agnostic framework designed to detect factual errors in texts generated by Large Language Models (LLMs). FacTool addresses the challenges of factual error detection in LLM-generated texts, such as the lack of clearly defined granularity for individual facts and the scarcity of explicit evidence available during fact-checking. The framework consists of five main components: claim extraction, query generation, tool querying, evidence collection, and agreement verification. FacTool leverages various tools, including Google Search, Google Scholar, code interpreters, Python, or even LLMs themselves, to gather evidence about the factuality of the generated content. The framework was evaluated on four different tasks: knowledge-based QA, code generation, math problem solving, and scientific literature review, demonstrating its efficacy.

takeaways.headline: FacTool Enhances Factual Error Detection in LLM-Generated Texts
takeaways.description: FacTool provides a unified and versatile framework for factual error detection across a variety of domains and tasks. It leverages the reasoning abilities of LLMs to assess the factuality of the content, given the evidence that has been gathered. The framework's ability to use tools in LLMs is crucial for factuality detection. For instance, it can use Google Search to gather evidence about the factuality of the generated content in knowledge-based QA, or use Python to verify the correctness of code snippets in code generation tasks. This makes FacTool a valuable tool for improving the usefulness and reliability of the content generated by LLMs.
takeaways.example: For instance, in a knowledge-based QA task, FacTool can extract claims from the generated text, generate queries to search for evidence on Google, collect the search results as evidence, and then use the LLM to verify the factuality of the claims based on the collected evidence. This process can help identify factual errors in the generated text, improving the accuracy and reliability of the answers provided by the LLM.

novelty_analysis: FacTool presents a novel approach to factual error detection in LLM-generated texts. It extends the conventional definition of factuality and introduces a task and domain-agnostic framework that can be applied across various tasks. The use of tools in LLMs for factuality detection is a unique feature of FacTool, making it a significant contribution to the field.
technical_analysis: The paper is somewhat technical, detailing the design and implementation of the FacTool framework. It discusses the challenges of factual error detection in LLM-generated texts and presents a solution in the form of a tool-augmented framework. The paper also provides a detailed evaluation of the framework on four different tasks, demonstrating its effectiveness.
enjoyable_analysis: The paper is well-structured and provides a comprehensive overview of the FacTool framework. It presents a novel approach to a significant challenge in the field of LLMs, making it an engaging read for those interested in the practical applications of LLMs. The detailed evaluation of the framework also provides valuable insights into its performance and potential applications.
